1. Introduce the crate gradually: Start by introducing your puppy to the crate during the day. Leave the door open, place some treats or toys inside, and encourage your puppy to explore and enter the crate voluntarily.

2. Use positive reinforcement: When your puppy enters the crate on their own, immediately praise and reward them with treats or toys. Repeat this several times a day until your puppy is comfortable in the crate.

3. Establish a bedtime routine: Create a consistent bedtime routine that includes putting your puppy in their crate for the night. This routine should include things like turning off the lights, saying goodnight to your puppy, and giving them a treat or special toy to keep them occupied.

4. Gradually increase crate time: Gradually increase the amount of time your puppy spends in the crate. Start with short periods of time, and gradually increase to longer periods.

5. Ignore whining or barking: When your puppy is in the crate at night, they may whine or bark to get your attention. It is important to ignore this behavior and wait until your puppy settles down. Reward calm behavior with treats or toys.

6. Provide comfort items: Provide your puppy with a comfortable bed, a blanket, and a few toys to make their crate more inviting and cozy.

7. Stay consistent: Consistency is key when training a puppy to stay in their crate. Stick to a routine, be patient, and always use positive reinforcement to encourage good behavior.
